dcXqhMqhZUo.title: Data Analytics vs Data Science
dcXqhMqhZUo.transcript:
0.4s: Data science and data analytics. Are they the 
same thing? Well, you may have seen these terms  
8.08s: used interchangeably, but if I'm mining data from 
a large dataset, am I performing data science or  
15.24s: am I performing data analytics? Or what if I'm 
trying to create a prediction of when my store  
20.84s: will sell out of our current inventory of 
cantaloupes? Well, is that analytics or is  
27.68s: that science? It's worthwhile to understand the 
difference to better comprehend what these two  
33.76s: fields can do, and also, if you're considering 
a career in either field. After all, these are two  
40.2s: different jobs. Somebody who works in the field 
of data science is known as a data scientist.  
49.36s: For data analytics, that role is called a data 
analyst. Now, this is kind of a trick question  
59.44s: because we can classify everything-- data 
mining, data forecasting and all the rest of  
65.12s: it --as simply data science. And that's because 
data science is the overarching umbrella term  
72.32s: that covers tasks related to finding patterns in 
large datasets, training machine learning models,  
77.56s: and deploying AI applications. Data analytics, it 
could be argued, is one task that resides under  
86.88s: the data science umbrella. It's a specialization 
of data science, and it focuses on querying,  
94.04s: interpreting and visualizing datasets. Data 
science is iterative, meaning data scientists form  
101.76s: hypotheses and experiments to see if a desired 
outcome can be achieved using available data.  
107.52s: And that is a process that is known as the data 
science lifecycle, which usually follows seven  
116.96s: phases. So first is to identify a problem or an 
opportunity. Then the next phase is data mining,  
126.36s: which is to extract data relevant to that problem 
or opportunity from large datasets. Now that data  
132.64s: will likely consist of a bunch of redundancies 
and errors, which is fixed in the next stage,  
138.88s: data cleaning. And then at that point, we move on 
to data exploration analysis to try to make sense  
146.92s: of that data. We'll then apply feature engineering 
using domain knowledge to extract details from the  
154.36s: data. And predictive modeling comes next to use 
the data to predict or forecast future outcomes  
162.24s: and behaviors. And then finally, we have data 
visualization that represents the data points with  
169.04s: graphical tools such as charts and animations. 
And so the lifecycle repeats. Now, the role of a  
174.4s: data scientist is an in-demand profession right 
now. If that's something you're interested in,  
179.76s: you'll want to develop deep skills in machine 
learning and AI. It's helpful to be able to  
184.92s: write code in languages such as Python--also in R-- 
it's another popular language for data science. And  
194.08s: you should have experience working with big data 
platforms. So perhaps Hadoop or Apache Spark. And  
202.6s: it's also very helpful to have database knowledge 
and SQL. So that's data science. But what about  
210.44s: its specialization, data analytics? Well, the job 
of a data analyst is to conceptualize a data set  
219.16s: as it currently exists. So we have some data 
here and we need to do something with it. And  
228.32s: we need to be able to make decisions based on 
this data. How do we conceptualize it? Well,  
233.84s: four ways. One is through predictive analytics, 
which helps to identify trends, correlations and  
240.6s: causation within datasets like forecasting when 
those cantaloupes would have all flown off the  
246.88s: shelves. Or, in health care, to forecast regions 
which will experience a rise in flu cases. There's  
253.68s: prescriptive analytics, and that predicts likely 
outcomes and makes decision recommendations like  
259.76s: predicting when a tire will wear out and need 
to be replaced. There's diagnostic analytics  
266.2s: that helps pinpoint the reason an event occurred. 
Manufacturers can analyze a failed component on an  
271.88s: assembly line and figure out the reason behind its 
failure. And then there is descriptive analytics  
278.64s: which evaluates the qualities and quantities of 
a data set. A content streaming provider might  
284.12s: use descriptive analytics to understand how many 
subscribers it's lost or how many it's gained over  
289.36s: a given period of time and what content is being 
watched. And while a data scientist is a clearly  
296.8s: defined and specialized role, virtually any 
stakeholder can be a data analyst. For example,  
303.84s: business analysts can use BI dashboards to conduct 
business analytics and visualize KPIs. But many  
310.28s: organizations do employ professional, dedicated 
data analysts, responsible for data wrangling  
316.96s: and interpreting findings like why a company's 
marketing campaign didn't meet expectations. If  
322.44s: you want to be a data analyst, it helps to have 
both analytical and programming skills. So this  
329.56s: includes familiarity with databases. Also, you'll 
need to know about statistical analysis. And also  
338.92s: data visualization is another important skill. 
So data analytics is often more focused on using  
347.48s: statistical tools and techniques to interpret 
existing data and offer actionable insights.  
353.56s: It's usually less concerned with creating 
new algorithms or models. Data science,  
358.2s: on the other hand, has a broader scope that can 
involve complex machine learning algorithms, often  
363.48s: created from scratch. Data science focuses 
on phases from data collection to predictive  
369.4s: modeling. Data analysis, on the other hand, is 
more about answering specific questions with  
375.72s: that data. And if you've done both your 
data science and data analytics right,  
382.48s: you'll always be able to keep cantaloupes 
and just about everything else in stock.
